stem: A 66-year-old client who is 3 days post-hip replacement suddenly screams, 'I can't breathe!' and clutches his chest. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute respiratory distress in a post-surgical client.
Background: The client is a 66-year-old female, 3 days post-right hip arthroplasty. BMI is 34, with a history of tobacco use. The client is currently on bed rest with sequential compression devices (SCDs) in place.
Assessment: At 14:30, the client reported sudden onset chest pain that worsens with inspiration (pleuritic). Skin is dusky and pale. Vital signs indicate respiratory distress.
Recommendation: Stat V/Q scan or CT Angiography is recommended to rule out pulmonary embolism. Consider immediate anticoagulation therapy.

tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content: BP 132/86, HR 118, RR 32, SpO2 84% on RA. Client is gasping for air.

actionOptions.text: Elevate the head of the bed (HOB) to 45–90 degrees
Initiate an IV Heparin infusion as prescribed
Encourage the client to ambulate to improve circulation
Apply heat packs to the right calf for comfort

parameterOptions.text: Continuous pulse oximetry and respiratory rate
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: This is a classic Pulmonary Embolism (c2) triggered by post-surgical immobility. Key findings: Pleuritic chest pain, acute hypoxia (SpO2 84%), tachycardia, tachypnea, and a high D-Dimer. Priority actions: Optimizing gas exchange via HOB elevation (a1) facilitates lung expansion and oxygenation. Stopping clot propagation with Heparin (a2) prevents further emboli. Key parameters: Continuous oxygenation/RR monitoring (p1) tracks respiratory stability. aPTT (p2) is essential to manage the therapeutic range of Heparin, preventing over- or under-anticoagulation.
clinicalPearls: In a PE emergency, remember: 'Up with the HOB, On with the O2.'
Heparin does NOT dissolve the existing clot; it prevents further clot formation, allowing the body’s own fibrinolytic system to dissolve the existing clot.
The gold standard for PE diagnosis is Computed Tomography Pulmonary Angiography (CTPA).

questionTrap.trap: Encouraging ambulation in a patient with a suspected PE.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Ambulation is crucial for VTE prevention, but contraindicated with an acute PE. If they have a PE, moving around could dislodge more emboli or worsen the cardiac strain. Bed rest and anticoagulation are the priorities.

mnemonic.title: PE Cues
mnemonic.expansion: P-Pleuritic pain. E-Emergency HOB elevation. E-Elevated D-Dimer.
